ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Applications for transfer of flats)


    1. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board the number of outstanding applications for transfer of flats, as at the latest convenient date, of applicants whose family membership consists of (i) 5 to 7 persons; (ii) 8 to 10 persons; and (iii) 11 or more persons; and against these family membership groupings, the number of applicants who have waited for one year and under; two years; three years; and four years and over.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the information requested

Column: 531

for by the Member for Mountbatten is as follows: 

Waiting Period of         No, of families consisting of

Transfer of Flats          5-7       8-10    11 or more

                    	 Persons   Persons     Persons



(a)Less than 1 year        358       137         20



(b)Between 1 to 2 years    365        46          3



(c)Between 2 to 3 years    187         8         30



(d)Between 3 to 4 years    371        75          7



(e)More than 4 years       390       178         60


    473 of the 628 applications which are in the 4-years or more waiting period have been offered alternative accommodation at least once, while some have been offered flats more than once. The remaining cases have not been considered because of their lower priority, such as requests for transfer to a similar type of flats or because of unsuitable locality or trouble with neighbours.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware of the fact that the applications for transfer to larger accommodation come mainly from one-room flat dwellers who cannot afford to buy flats under the home ownership scheme? Will the Minister urge the Housing and Development Board to speed up the processing of these applications?

    With particular reference to those living in my constituency, will the Minister request the Housing Board not to reserve all the casual vacant flats for resettlement purposes but to release some of these vacant flats, wherever possible, for my constituents who are on the waiting list? Sir, most of these constituents have lived in my constituency for more than a decade and they prefer to be transferred within the estate.

    Mr Barker: Sir, after that long speech by the Member, I do not get what the question is. If it is a question of expediting the processing of applications, this can be done. But the number of flats are limited and the number of applications are many.

    As for the Member's own estate, particularly Old Kallang Airport estate and the Guillemard Road estate, I have details of outstanding applications for

Column: 532

transfer. The number of families consisting of 5-7 persons in these estates who waited for more than four years are about 33; families of 8-10 persons who waited for more than four years number only two; and the number of families consisting of 11 or more persons who had to wait for more than a year does not exist. In fact, only two families of such a number have waited for less than a year. Most of the flats vacated existing tenants in the two estates that I have referred to have been allocated, in fact, to transfer-applicants from these estates. Of the 46 units vacated in 1973, 34 units were allocated to transfer cases in respect of residents from these two estates. Only two flats were allocated to resettlement cases and the remaining flats to public applicants and fire victims from elsewhere. In fact, I do not know what the Member of Parliament is grumbling about.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1974 TO 31ST MARCH, 1975



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [4th Allotted Day].

    Resumption of Debate on Question (20th March, 1974),

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head JA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AA 1004.". - [Mr Teong Eng Siong].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.35 p.m.

    Head JA -

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the fact that the Minister is absent and I have something to discuss with him, I do not know what to do. Perhaps when he comes in, I may raise my question. But for now, I want to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps after that little confusion I may be allowed to move my amendment. Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head JA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AC 1201.

Column: 533



    Sir, I am not against anti-smoking. This amendment is moved in order to seek clarification only. The Anti-Smoking Advertisement Unit has an appropriation of about $46,000 for the financial year 1974. What does this Unit do, Sir? As far as I know, occasionally we see frightening anti-smoking advertisements on TV and anti-smoking posters on notice boards. Other than this, is this Unit responsible for anything else? If this is all that they do, then could not this work be done by the Publicity Division of the Ministry of Culture, which has an appropriation of about $2 million? In these days of manpower shortage, to tie up one Division II officer and five Division III officers in this little Anti-Smoking Unit is a luxury that we can ill-afford.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the primary function of the Unit is to watch the mass media to ensure that no cigarette advertisements are being publicised contrary to the law. Other duties of the Anti-Smoking Unit include routine and systematic checks for cigarette advertisements in hotels, cinemas, theatres, bars, restaurants, markets, villages, etc; dealing with applications for exemption under the Act and, where exemptions have been granted, to check on the advertisements, be they on vehicles, printed matter or signboards; and vetting imported cigarette advertisement materials.

    So far the work has been satisfactory and there is very little or no infringement of the law, as most of the newspapers and other publications know these restrictions. We have already done the job. I quite agree with the Member that it is high time we abolished this Unit, and the staff absorbed into the administration unit of the Ministry of Culture, or the Publicity Division, as he has suggested.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: What else can I do, Sir, but to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

Column: 534



    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head JA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BA 1109.

    Sir, what sort of censorship is imposed on the presentation of commercial advertisements over TV Singapore? Some advertisements show youths with long hair romping around speaking of the virtues of a cough mixture. Surely advertisements of this nature could have been done away with.

    Even in the press some advertisements with dubious claims are still being published. Often the victims are women. For example, there is an advertisement that claims to reduce a person's weight in minutes. The people who answered these advertisements claimed that they have been swindled, as the services provided were not in accord with what these advertisements claimed. Again, there was another advertisement showing a quack doctor recommending a certain drug for certain cures. This is mere propaganda. An advertisement of this nature is misleading and the advertiser is only interested in swindling people of their honest earnings.

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Sir, the vote on this subhead is to be allocated for the Head of the Publicity Division. The Publicity Division of the Ministry of Culture has no control over TV or newspaper advertisements. However, as for the advertisements on TV, the Broadcasting Department sees to it that every TV commercial submitted to the Department for use is subjected to two separate censorship viewings, first, by the Commercial Division and, second, by a panel of viewers under the charge of the film organiser. In both these areas, strict control is exercised to ensure that the content of the commercial, both radio and visual, adheres strictly to RTS programme code and copy policy.

    Many commercials depicting persons with long hair have been rejected, although these entail a loss of revenue. From January 1973 to date, the Department has rejected 29 filmlets on this ground. The corresponding figure in respect of slides is four. My officials in

Column: 535

the Broadcasting Department are unable to recall any commercial showing youths with long hair romping round extolling the virtues of a cough mixture. Such a commercial would not have been allowed for telecast.

2.45 p.m.

    As for the content of advertisements inserted in the press, my Ministry does not censor them. If the public is cheated by dishonest advertisements, I think the matter should more appropriately be dealt with by the Police, and reports made to them. However, if my Ministry finds that any particular advertisement appearing in the newspapers is morally objectionable, my Ministry will advise the newspaper concerned to stop carrying such advertisements further.

    For the control of advertisements relating to medical matters, this function is also outside the purview of my Ministry. Such matters are governed by the Medicines (Advertisement and Sale) Act which is administered by the Ministry of Health. For advertisements over TV in which medical claims are made in respect of certain drugs and cures, the Broadcasting Department insists on some form of supporting evidence or material. For example, if a claim is made in a commercial that a certain drug is recommended by doctors, then the Department of Broadcasting requires the advertiser to substantiate that such recommendations have been actually made by doctors. If there is any doubt regarding such claims, then the Department of Broadcasting will refer the matter to the Ministry of Health.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture said that the Publicity Division does not have any control over advertisements. What then is the duty of the Publicity Division? And are advertisements controlled by the Ministry of Culture or some other Ministry? Is the Publicity Division controlled by the Ministry of Culture or some other Ministry? I do not know why the Parliamentary Secretary keeps on mentioning that that is not under his jurisdiction. I do not understand. Mr Speaker, Sir, 1 want my questions answered.

Column: 536



    The Chairman: Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary can explain again.

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Sir, I thought I have already answered the question of TV commercials. As I said, TV commercials do not come under the Publicity Division. It comes under the Broadcasting Department of the Ministry of Culture. I have already explained that because of this, other matters which are not related to the Ministry of Culture, for instance, this question of medicines or quack doctors and whatnots, come under different Ministries. I hope the Member for Anson is satisfied with this explanation.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot get a correct answer from the Parliamentary Secretary. The Minister for Culture is supposed to be the person who approves these advertisements. Right or wrong, it must be referred to the Ministry concerned before approval is given. Now, is not the Broadcasting Department under the Ministry of Culture? Therefore, the Ministry should take action. But he has said that this matter comes under Broadcasting. Broadcasting - which department, which Ministry? Ministry of Culture, is it not? So why is he confusing the issue? He should not avoid my question, but give a straight answer.

    The Chairman: Do you want him to explain again?

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Yes.

    The Chairman: By all means. Haji Sha'ari Tadin.

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said earlier, the Publicity Division of the Ministry of Culture has no control over newspaper advertisements. I thought I have made that clear. Of course, if anybody or any reader has been cheated through newspaper advertisements, he can make a report to the Police. And following that, the Police will have to take action. We have the Film Censorship Board, which has the control over advertisements on films, but it has no control over advertisements in the newspapers.

Column: 537



    Mr P. Govindaswamy: That is an unsatisfactory reply. The Broadcasting Department comes under the Ministry of Culture. Why is he referring to Broadcasting? His Ministry is the responsible Ministry to take any action. But why did he say that the Publicity Division does not control Broadcasting but the Minister for Culture controls the Broadcasting Department? I am very sorry for this barrage of questions. However, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampung Kembangan)(In Malay): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head JA be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead CA 1107*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy)

    Mr Speaker, Sir, inflation which is prevailing now throughout the world, including Singapore, is causing prices to rise, and rise still higher from day to day. Therefore, I think it is inappropriate for the Minister for Culture to spend $10.2 million to implement the plan for colour TV in Singapore. The sum to be allocated can be better used by other Ministries for projects that are more beneficial to the people of Singapore.

    Sir, workers in the low-income group are still hoping for a sympathetic gesture from the Government by giving them a higher salary, so that they can meet the rising cost of living, as prices are very high now. Therefore, it would be better for the sum of $10.2 million to be channelled elsewhere, so that people in the low-income group can get more. The Minister himself and the Prime Minister have suggested to the people not to spend money unnecessarily. But when the Ministry of Culture implements TV programmes in colour, people will buy colour television sets. Although the Ministry does not encourage people to buy colour sets, nevertheless the people will be inclined and influenced into buying colour sets on instalment basis. And by paying in instalments, the price

Column: 538

will definitely be higher, and this will further affect their cost of living, making it more difficult for them. Therefore, I think it would be better for the Ministry of Culture to postpone the introduction of colour television to next year or to some other appropriate time, when inflation has subsided and when economic conditions in Singapore have improved.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, the standard of broadcasting is quite poor. Some of the announcers swallow their words. I believe the reason is that broadcasters are chosen from their paper qualifications rather than their broadcasting abilities. This should not be the case. Language proficiency is very important. It does not take a very highly qualified person to be announcers. Therefore, I suggest that fluency and proficiency in the language medium should be considered when selecting candidates for the post. If not, they should be sent for training.

    Why is the standard of locally produced programmes so poor? Is it because our producers are not properly trained? Most of our programmes are imported since we lack expertise in producing scripts. Why we do not get foreign experts to train our people? I also heard that the payments made to the artistes are very low, but if foreigners come, they pay more money. If an artiste is to sing just a song over TV, he or she has to go through a number of auditions, before the final scene is shot. Surely something could be done about this. After all the fuss, the artiste is paid a miserable mite.

    How is it that the same faces appear again and again on our local TV programmes? We cannot get other persons -only those persons! Something is definitely wrong somewhere. What efforts are being made to introduce new blood of screen artistes? Is there a clique system in the auditioning section? Probably the system of auditioning artistes has to be reviewed to give more people a chance to come forward to participate.

Column: 539



    Most of the programmes in the English Section are imported ones. Even the plays are BBC-produced. Surely with a large English-speaking population we should be able to produce some plays over TV and Radio. There are some local theatrical groups whose performances are good. Why not televise them and thereby encourage them? How successful has the Broadcasting Department been in attracting people to contribute songs and drama with local colour, or have the miserable prizes it offers not brought in any contributions?

    Sometime ago, one could view TV documentaries quite often. Documentaries, as one knows, have a very great educational value and for Singapore in particular, where the population is young, these documentaries will enhance the concepts of this world. It is time RTS introduced more documentaries rather than pop singers who were idols sometime ago.

    Sir, in the last Budget session, I pointed out the wrong pronunciation of the word "million" by the Tamil announcers. The Tamil language is very old. But the Tamil announcers do not seem to know the word "million" in Tamil. They use the English word "million". Last year, I mentioned about this and I told them not to use "million". If they speak Tamil, use purely the Tamil words. Why must they mix English and Tamil together? If there is no such word in the Tamil language, then there is no harm. But there is a word for "million" in Tamil. Up to-date no effort has been made to rectify this error. Why is this so? When a Member of Parliament shouts out his complaints here, is that the end of the matter, closed up and finished? If so, what is the use of talking, talking, and talking again?

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, I share the sentiments expressed by the Member for Kampung Kembangan. However, I am most concerned as to whether it is most appropriate to introduce colour television at the present time. I believe there are approximately 250,000 black and white TV sets in use

Column: 540

at the moment. With the introduction of colour TV, it is expected that a large number of people, as has been pointed out earlier on, would want to switch from black and white to colour TV I have made a very quick calculation. Assuming that only 25 per cent of the people want colour television, it would mean a total expenditure of approximately $62 million, based on $1,000 per set which is the figure given to me by the Minister for Culture. If everybody wants to change over to colour, the total expenditure would come to $250 million. As most television sets are imported, or even if they are assembled here, most of the parts would still have to come from abroad, and the total spending of the public would be a drain on our hard-earned foreign exchange.

    Sir, as pointed out earlier on, while we are urging people on the one hand to tighten their belts and to cut down on personal spending and save, on the other hand, it would appear that we are acting against our own policy. This is a glaring example of the occasional lack of consistency in the implementation of Government policies, suggesting that the left hand often does not know what the right hand is doing. Government departments are not the only guilty parties in this respect. State-owned enterprises are much worse. I am sure Members' attention has been drawn in recent weeks to huge advertising spaces taken up by the Singapore Airlines enticing people to take their holidays abroad. This is at a time when the nation is faced with an extra oil deal of some $200 million, as pointed out by the Minister for Finance. Every effort should be made to conserve our hard-earned foreign exchange, rather than to squander it away on non-essentials which would only affect our balance of payments position.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, after listening to the Member for Jalan Kayu and his calculations, I am sure that he did not take into consideration what the Ministry of Culture has been thinking of. Somehow or other, knowing our Finance Minister and the Minister for Culture, I have no doubt that they are thinking of increasing the rates for

Column: 541

TV licences. That may also add to the unnecessary spending. When the Minister or his Parliamentary Secretary gives an answer to this subhead, I would be happy if he could let me know whether or not there is any intention to increase the TV licence charges when colour TV is introduced.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, I also support the Member for Kampung Kembangan and the Member for Jalan Kayu. I feel that colour TV should not be introduced into Singapore until such time when the populace - I am talking about the lower income group - and the various community centres are able to afford installing such television sets.

    In addition to that, there is a technical point too. At the present moment, colour TV does not cover the whole spectrum. Many countries in the world, like Japan and the United States of America, are going to step up development to have colour TV that would cover the whole spectrum. This would most certainly be an advantage because at the present moment colours in real life are not faithfully reproduced on colour TV.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year when we were discussing colour television, there was an overwhelming demand for colour television. The time was good then and nobody had expected that we were going to have the oil crisis, and so on. Now suddenly everybody is complaining that it would be extravagant to spend money on colour television. However, I believe that if the viewer does not want a colour set, he can still receive black and white programmes.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I share the sentiments expressed by the Member for Jalan Kayu over the need to be thrifty. But, as I have pointed out in the Budget debate on Friday, people are beginning to wonder whether it is now worthwhile to save. As I have said, the new-found philosophy seems to be "spend and enjoy now, die later", simply because of the depreciation of the real value of

Column: 542

money. In Singapore, whether it is this year, next year or ten years later, we must keep up with the times. We must have colour television. It is better to have it now, because if a colour television set costs $1,000 today I think it would probably cost $1,500 in two years' time.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): It may be in six months' time.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Or in six months' time, and this would be a further drain on our foreign exchange as we have to pay more for the import of colour TV sets. I think colour television is a necessary form of entertainment. It is much more attractive than black and white. It is one way of keeping the people at home so that they would not waste their money seeking entertainment outside their homes.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, touching on the topic of colour television, I am amazed by the rather spontaneous reactions that we hear today in Parliament against the introduction of colour television. As the Member for Bras Basah rightly pointed out, last year there was unanimous applause for the introduction of colour television and this year a sudden reverse reaction,

    I hesitate really to say that we should proceed with colour television because, to my mind, there must surely be very good reasons behind the Ministry of Culture's intention to introduce colour television. But we are faced with the problem of international inflation and the rise in oil prices, and this should certainly be a new factor in our financial calculations. I therefore do not wish to goad the Minister for Culture head-on to the introduction of colour television. At the same time, I think it is appropriate for the Ministry to sit down and have a serious calculation, working forwards and backwards, to find out if in fact we should proceed with colour television. And if it is convinced that it is necessary then we carry on.

    The Member for Moulmein has correctly pointed out that introducing colour television in two years' time might

Column: 543

mean a lot more money. We can foresee that if colour television were not introduced by that time, some Backbenchers or some Members on the Government side might come up and say, "Look, two years ago you were against it."

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, I think I ought to clarify myself. When I spoke against colour television, I am not against having colour television as such, but it is a question of timing. Take our financial policy, for instance. Last year we encouraged people to spend because times were good. But now because of inflation and other factors, as part and parcel of our anti-inflation measures, the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Ministry of Finance have introduced a whole series of credit squeeze measures. As we all know, the credit squeeze is on. I am not saying that we must not have colour TV. The fact that there was a demand last year and now we are suggesting that there should be a changed attitude is totally immaterial to the point I am trying to make, i.e, the consistency of Government policy. The policy and the implementation thereof should be consistent. That is the main point I am trying to emphasise.

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Mr Speaker, Sir, before answering the Member for Kampung Kembangan and other Members who have suggested that the Government delay the introduction of colour TV in view of the present inflation and high prices which may cause a social burden to our people, let me answer the question by the Member for Sembawang first, as the Deputy Speaker had ruled yesterday that the Member's question could be answered together with the others in respect of subhead CA 1107, for which there is an amendment.

    The Member for Sembawang had asked my Minister yesterday when colour TV would be ready. And before I could give an answer, some Members had also, in fact, dwelt on the subject. Television Singapore will be radiating colour TV Trade and Test Transmissions consisting of Test Pattern, slides and

Column: 544

films as from 2nd May, 1974. These transmissions will be radiated on: 

 Channel  5:   Weekdays   from   10 a.m, to  12 noon 

               and 2 p.m, to 3 p.m.

               Saturdays  from   10 a.m, to  12 noon.



 Channel  8:  Weekdays in between ETV programme slots

                  (Test Pattern only)

              Saturdays,  Sundays and Public Holidays 

              from 2 p.m, to 3 p.m.


    A pilot colour TV service will be inaugurated in August, 1974. Film programmes from overseas and local documentary films will be scheduled for telecast on both channels during normal transmission hours. The number of such programmes in colour will be limited to a duration of one to two hours a day.

    Equipment orders for studio and outside broadcast productions have already been placed, and an extension to the pilot service will be effected when these equipment are delivered and installed.

    Now, Mr Speaker, Sir, coming back to the suggestion by the Member for Kampung Kembangan and also other Members that Government delay the introduction of colour TV, which Members have also expressed concern, may I be allowed, Sir, to inform Members that we cannot accede to their request because, as Members will recollect, in January, 1972, Government approved the introduction of colour TV. The whole project costs over $20 million over a period of four years. This House has accordingly voted $2.9 million last year for the project. Since then, a number of tenders have been called for the purchase of equipment.

    Our present black and white television service was inaugurated in February, 1963. This means that most of the equipment at our TV station is over 10 years old, and is due for replacement due to usage and fair wear and tear It would, therefore, be economically sound at this stage when replacing the equipment to introduce colour television. Moreover, if we were to defer this project, Singapore will be amongst the last of the South-east Asian countries to further develop its television service. Thailand and the Philippines introduced colour television a couple of years ago.

Column: 545



3.15 p.m.

    If we were to abandon the project at this juncture, it would also mean that we would not be able to fully utilise some of the equipment which we ordered and which was delivered before the energy crisis. In this respect, I would like to thank the Members for Kim Seng, Bras Basah and Moulmein who have expressed their support on the introduction of colour TV.
